tn.ref: How long will you mourn for Saul, since I have rejected him from being king over Israel?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is a rebuke from God and can be translated as a statement. AT: "Stop mourning that I rejected Saul from being king over Israel." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The term "horn" was sometimes used to refer to a "flask" that was shaped like a horn and was used for holding water or oil. A flask of oil was used for anointing a king.
Samuel uses a question to emphasize that he is worried about going to Bethlehem. AT: "I cannot go!" or "I am afraid to go." (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
You can state the understood information. AT: "with you to Bethlehem and say to the people there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: and say, 'I have come to sacrifice to Yahweh.'
tn.text: This has a quotation within a quotation. The direct quotation can be stated as an indirect quotation. AT: "and say to the people there that you have come to sacrifice to Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotesinquotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])

tn.ref: The elders of the city were trembling as they came to meet him
tn.text: It seems the elders were trembling because they were worried that Samuel came to rebuke them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
This can be stated as a complete sentence. AT: "Yes, I have come in peace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
To set someone apart means to get that person ready for Yahweh's purposes by making sure that person is ritually clean according to the law of Moses.
Here "they" refers to Jesse and his sons.
Here "he" refers to Samuel.
This is the name of Jesse's oldest son. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Here "him" refers to Yahweh.

tn.ref: Yahweh does not see as man sees
tn.text: Here "see" means to evaluate something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: For Yahweh does not see ... Yahweh looks
tn.text: Yahweh is speaking about himself in the third person. AT: "For I, Yahweh, do not see ... I, Yahweh, look" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
Here "heart" represents a person's inner being. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These are names of Jesse's sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"told him to go to Samuel"

tn.ref: Jesse then made Shammah pass by
tn.text: It is understood that Shammah passed by Samuel. AT: "Jesse then made Shammah pass before Samuel" or "Jesse then told Shammah to go to Samuel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"There is still my youngest son"
It is understood that they were waiting to sit down and eat. AT: "we will not sit down to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
The word "Now" is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the narrator tells about a new person in the story.
The word "ruddy" means David was healthy looking.

The term "horn" was sometimes used to refer to a "flask" that was shaped like a horn and was used for holding water or oil. A flask of oil was used for anointing a king. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:16:01|16:1]].
It is implied that he rose up after they sat down to eat. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The Spirit of Yahweh rushed on David
tn.text: The phrase "rushed on" means Yahweh's Spirit influenced David. In this case it means he enabled David to fulfill whatever Yahweh wanted him to do. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:10:05|10:6]].
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the narrator starts to tell a new part of the story.
This may refer to either a "spirit that causes trouble" or an "evil spirit."
The servants refer to Saul in the third person as "our master." AT: "We ask that you, our master, command" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: command your servants who are before you to look
tn.text: The servants refer to themselves in the third person as "your servants." AT: "command us, your servants who attend to you, to look" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
"troubles you"
Possible meanings are 1) "a great warrior" or 2) "a very brave man."
"one wise in speech" or "one who speaks wisely"
Here "with him" means Yahweh helps and blesses David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here "came" can be translated as "went." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
The abstract noun "service" can be stated as a verb. AT: "and began to serve him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"David became Saul's armor bearer"
Here "stand before me" is an idiom that means to continue in Saul's service. AT: "Let David stay in my service" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he has found favor in my sight
tn.text: Here "my sight" represents how Saul judges or evaluates David. AT: "he has found favor in my judgment" or "I am pleased with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "harmful spirit" may refer to either a "spirit that causes trouble" or an "evil spirit." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1sa:16:14|16:14]].
"troubled Saul"

tn.ref: Saul would be refreshed and well
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the music would refresh Saul and make him well" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
